Subject: Combining NSGA-II and NEAT speciated fitness sharing
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=234577593; y=zmN5m1BwkbpoiGOhe2Hkti_IVUOe_yZGH_UW-0RDj9bc7Ci-6pnRMxVM2aWC8nNqSdbBp6W8dA

--089e01493538f0e75e04df036269
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1

Hi all,

I have another implementation kind of question (I was hoping I would
realise the answer once I wrote it out, but that didn't happen!):

I'm implementing the NSGA-II multi-objective EA method in my (Hyper)NEAT
software (https://github.com/OliverColeman/ahni). I'd like to continue
using speciation and fitness sharing (according to species). It seems I
need to try and merge the NEAT algorithm and the NSGA-II algorithm, which
comes down to something like:

Evaluate fitness of entire population
Speciate
Foreach generation
Create offspring from existing population
Select parents (using speciated fitness)
Reproduce
Apply mutation operators
Add offspring to population (NOTE: the population size is now temporarily
bigger than the desired size)
Evaluate fitness of entire population (some fitness values would need to be
recalculated (eg novelty) but not others)
Speciate
Rank and sort population by non-dominance *(**separately within each
species? If not then **using original fitness OR shared fitness as
determined by speciation?)*
Cull population by successively removing lowest ranked sets (within each
species) until the desired pop size is reached (is slightly more
complicated than this)

I'm wondering first whether it would be best to do the ranking and sorting
separately within each species, and if not then is it a good idea to use
speciated fitness (as determined by NEAT) when ranking and sorting.

If not ranking and sorting separately within each species, then a reason
for using speciated fitness when ranking and sorting is that speciated
fitness sharing helps protect innovation and the ranking and sorting
determines which members of the population (which at this point includes
the previous population and the new offspring) will remain for the next
generation. A possible reason against is that it might "skew" the results
of the ranking and sorting procedure (which is intended to find the "real"
Pareto fronts/sets). Perhaps as long as the elites (according to each
objective) are maintained in a species then it doesn't matter much one way
or the other.

(Note that there are two selection stages being employed: the one to select
parents to produce offspring (which I think should be the same as that for
NEAT: mating within species, etc), and the one to reduce the population,
after adding offspring to it, to the desired population size).

I hope the above makes sense, let me know if anything is ambiguous, etc.
Thanks in advance for any advice!

Cheers,
Oliver

T: 0421 972 953 | E: oliver.coleman@... | W: http://ojcoleman.com

--089e01493538f0e75e04df036269
